TL;DR: This game builds upon Lego Batman and DC Super Heroes. It improves controls and visuals, and offers a new, unique story. Combine this with a change of scenery, and you’ve got yourself a hit.

I’m not going to say much that others haven’t already said. But to sum it all up, this game is like “Lego Batman 2: DC Super Heroes” on steroids. All the classic features that made people love this game are present. That “Batman: Arkham City” style free roam. The “brain friendly” (detect sarcasm here) puzzles that made “Lego Indiana Jones” a hit. The powers of all your favorite childhood super heroes. And now, a story worthy of the game! If you’re like me, and have played any (or all) of these titles, you’ll get a major de ja vous.


The last two Lego Batman games were astounding, but this ramps up everything to a new level. As mentioned above (in other reviews), the graphics in this game are improved. And when I say improved, I don't mean a tiny bit, I mean A LOT. I know this might not be the best comparison to make here, but if any of you have ever played Minecraft with the R3DCraft resource pack and/or Shaders (SEUS) mod enabled, you might have an idea as to what I mean. For those that haven’t played Minecraft (haven’t played it seriously, I mean) try googling images of the Shaders mod. It’s a night and day difference between the standard shader pack. While the difference between “Beyond Gotham” and “DC Super Heroes” might not be quite THAT drastic, I think my example gives an accurate portrayal of how much better the game not only looks, but feels. And keep in mind, Lego Batman 2 was NOT a bad looking game. The change of scenery doesn’t hurt either. I love the fact that this game takes you places you don’t often get to go in the DC universe. It’s really quite refreshing. Honestly, I think that this game rivals even “Arkham City” in terms of the best Batman game. Well, that might be pushing it. But one thing’s certain: It’s certainly a great deal better thank “Lego Marvel Super Heroes”! :D


It sometimes boggles my mind; why make such a great title a Lego game? But in actuality, I think it’s that fact that makes the game as enjoyable as it is. For any newbies, don’t let the fact that it’s a Lego game discourage you; this game is definitely worth the play. I know as well as anyone that the constant sales sometimes, or often, make us want to spend no more than the price of a sandwich on a game. But this is one worth full price. Honestly guys, you should have picked up the Premium Edition yesterday!

P.S.  “Lego Batman 4: Justice League” anyone? XD

reviewText:
Lego Batman 3: Beyond Gotham is a solid Lego game for better and for worse. Sporting over 100 characters and numerous locations, Lego Batman 3 has to be the most expansive and diverse Lego game to date. However, platforming is still frustrating and at times it all just seems so overwhelming and underwhelming at the exact same time.

Lego Batman 3 from Traveler's Tale interactive is the 4th game in the Lego video game franchise to feature DC comics’ characters. The title “Lego Batman” is incredible loose at this point especially after 2012’s Lego Batman 2: DC Super Heroes added a bulk of the Justice League to the line-up. The story starts with Batman and Robin as they chase Killer Croc through the sewers of Gotham City. Meanwhile, the Joker, Lex Luthor, Solomon Grundy and Cheetah invade the Hall of Justice in order to take over the Watchtower, the Justice League’s space station.

Soon after the Justice League bring their villains under control in the Watchtower earth is invaded by Brainac who has stolen the power of all the Lantern Corps’. Using these powers, Brainac shrinks the earth and the Justice League and their villains have to work together to save the earth and free the Lantern Corps’ power.

The Lego franchise of video games have never bolstered a great story and the same goes for Lego Batman 3. The story primarily serves as a means to bring all of the DC comics diverse characters together. However, cute, clever, or down-right goofy events allow for fun and exciting moments. Early in the game Batman, under the control of Brainac, begins tearing apart the Bat Cave. I played as Alfred through most of the encounter and giggled when I got the chance to beat up Batman as his butler. Moments such as that are the highlights of the franchise.

Lego Batman 3 offers the same simple cooperative option as the previous titles. It is still fun working out side quests and free play mode of the story with another person. It also makes exploring the multiple hub worlds easier to manage. However, the dynamic screen split that started in Lego Indiana Jones is still confusing, but the option for a fixed screen split is still available. The co-op mode still remains the best way to truck through these games. It will always be more fun to bring a friend with you in the story missions.

Outside of the main story, Lego Batman 3 features several unique hub worlds to collect new characters and golden bricks (the trophies of the franchise). In the previous Lego titles Traveler's Tale has pushed to feature large open worlds that the characters need to explore. These huge worlds were overwhelming at best and rage inducing at worst as it made tracking down side quest difficult and confusing. Lego Batman 3 breaks away from that by only having a handful of hub areas that are incredibly easy to navigate. Side activities no longer feel as much of a chore now that the player can easily bounce from one to the next.

The side quests and who assigns them to the player is the real highlight of the game. From the expected characters such as Booster Gold and Aquaman, to unusual like Ace the Bat-Hound, Conan O'Brien and writer/director Kevin Smith. The game even features a prominent role from the Green Loontern, Looney Toons’ Daffy Duck with the powers of the Green Lantern. Traveler's Tale has gone out of their way to offer the silliest and most surprising cameos in this game. Seriously, the Bat-Cow is in this game.

The best and most surprising cameo in the game is a collectable that is devoted to Adam West. In the various story missions and hub worlds Adam West is in trouble and the player has to rescue him. During the first story mission I heard, “This is TV’s Adam West and I’m in trouble!” and I became immensely giddy. However, to save Mr. West I needed a character I had yet to unlock which was annoying and frustrating to encounter in the first mission.

The Lego games have always locked away secrets and goals behind unlockable characters, but this game seems to handle that in the worse ways. After completing the main story I had only completed 20% of game and was only able to unlock maybe 10% of the secrets hidden in the main story. The franchise has always been about replayability, but it would be nice to at least end the story unlocking more of that content

The Lego games have always had a fatigue associated with them. I love this series and have played a majority of the titles, but I have yet to 100% one of them. The Lego fatigue stems from a bloated run time and story missions that feel far too long. Story missions in this game took me between 45 minutes to an hour each and the thought of having to truck through one again for a single unlockable adds to the fatigue. I burned 24 hours in this game, but I doubt I will spend much more time in Lego Batman 3.

Excluding the bloated nature of this title I do feel like the franchise is improving. The platforming in the game is still terrible like all the previous Lego titles, but there is far less emphasis on jumping puzzles. Flying characters such as Wonder Woman and others are unlocked early in the story missions and aid in the navigation of the worlds. This is better than Lego Batman 2 where I had to wait till the very end of the game to unlock Wonder Woman.

Lego Batman 3: Beyond Gotham is proving to me that Traveler’s Tale is improving the franchise. The game is fun and a nice diversion during the crazy video game season that we are currently in. It is great for kids, a good time sink for any adult and almost a must play for any DC comics fan who will get excited at the thought of playing as Wonder Woman disguised as Cheetah. I am mainly referring to myself of course. Oh, and when you fly as Wonder Woman it plays the theme song to the 1970s Wonder Woman tv show! That detail and others make Lego Batman 3 a game worth playing.

As I write this review the Arrow DLC still has yet to drop so I'm basing this on having 100% this game with the current three dlcs out with the season pass.  First and foremost let me say how much I hated the storyline in this game.  For me it was the  worst of all the lego games I've played (the other Batmans, Harry Potter, Marvel, Indiana Jones, Pirates of the Caribbean, Lego Movie).  I will admit my biggest problem is that I'm not a big DC person.  I only like a few characters and Batman is one of them so when I buy a game called Lego Batman I expect the storyline to be promeniently about Batman.  This wasn't that.  This was Lego Green Lantern or Lego DC Universe but it wasn't Lego Batman.  I realize that they probably called it that to make more money but it really irks me.  Don't get me wrong I still had fun with the game, as I do with all the lego games.  I was just really looking forward to a batman centric story.  That being said I did not run into as many glitches as others have complained about.  I also played this game with the XBOX wired controller for Windows and never had a single problem with the controls as some other people have said.  The controller worked fine for me and I played all nearly 70 hours with it.

These are the glitches that I did run into however:
-The bat computer doesn't work in the bat cave to allow you to see levels and replay them even though Conan says it does.
-When you run over a heart after taking out an enemy it doesn't always add a heart to your meter if you are low.  This is a problem I also noticed in Lego Marvel but not as prevalent as here.
-When I was free playing the level Lantern Menance the game crashed on me three times.  There wasn't a checkpoint before each crash so I lost everything each time.  I had to save and exit a few times as well as start at a different point in the level then go back before I could get everything.  The game never crashed before or after this.  Only when I free played this level.
-Some of the Quests glitched in various ways.
-The rest were standard Lego glitches that are pretty much in every game.

Ok so I guess this is where I'll go through my pros and cons:
Pros:
-All the suits in this game can be accessed by holding down the Y button if you're using a controller, once you find the corresponding token.  Makes things a lot easier when you need different suits, also if you place the character by where they need to do the suit change sometimes you can just hit the B button and it will automatically change to the suit you need.  I liked this a lot better than the previous games.
-The Bonus Batman '66 level and the DLC levels which I enjoyed more than the game itself.  There's a lot of fun stuff there. Totally can't wait for the Arrow, Bizarro and Suicide Squad DLCs.
-Geoff Johns, Jim Lee, Kevin Smith, Adam West and the Green Loontern are playable characters which is just awesome.
-That they shut up Conan O'Brien in the last update so he only speaks if you walk up to him and hit the B button.  He's incessent talking was annoying before but you may want to talk to him the first time through just to get the lay of the land.
-managed to finish the entire game in two weeks and sixty-seven hours which isn't bad for a lego game.
-Voice acting was fun and good as it usually is since they started letting the characters speak.
-There are a plenty of characters in this game so have ample combinations for free play, quests and races
-There are many places to visit with quests and races including the bat cave (which has a room modeled after the batman tv show), the hall of justice, the watchtower, the seven lantern planets and a moon base
-Each free play level is broken up into different sections so you don't necessarily have to start from the beginning
-You can find unlocked red bricks in both the bat cave and the watchtower by going to the trophy room.  Much of what's in the watchtower is also in the bat cave so you can decide where you want to go.

Cons:
-This game has the fewest checkpoints I've ever seen for a lego game. This became a problem when I went on to free play as I mentioned above
-Couldn't access any free play levels or characters that were unlocked until after you got so far into the story.  Once you were done with the story you could access unlocked vehicles in Oa, unlocked characters by holding down the Y button or visiting one of the Lantern planets and free play levels from the control room in the watchtower.  It could sometimes be annoying to go from one to the other just to unlock something, especially since the bat computer didn't work.
-The map wasn't as good as Lego Marvel and when you got past a certain level in story mode you kept going back to the control room and had to find your next level on it.  I really didn't like that, it was a bit obnoxious.
-there are no extra hearts or invincible red bricks in this game, which could have been useful, but there's a ghost stud collector... except there is almost no ghost studs in this game.  Pretty stupid.
-VR Missions- I really hated these.  Almost threw my controller at my monitor a few times.  Need to do them to get some characters, vehicles and gold bricks though as well as complete a few missions. Was glad when they were done.

Overall I like the game and do recommend it though I wish there was more batman but I believe the dlcs in this game surpass anything they've done in the others and I can't wait to play them all.  Below are some tips and suggestions if you are not the kinda person who likes that stuff stop reading here.

Tips and suggestions:
-I found the red bricks for the gold brick detector, quest detector & adam west in peril detector were very useful on the hub planets
-If you are like me and like to get all the achievements then to get some of them do the following things: visit all the hub planets on a single gaming session; Jump on something 50 times in a row; the one with Krypto in the Man of Steel level you have to change both characters to Krypto; When you are in the control room there is a room to the right which you will need to go in for two of the achievements.
-Wait until you're done with story mode to do free play, it's just easier
-I found doing quests and stuff area by area worked best.
-On your way to Oa for the first time inspect the moon instead of going through the grate. There's an achievement with cows that isn't too hard to find.
-When in Oa I used the cars for the land races (Flash's Car worked best for me) but I used flying characters for all the air races because the planes flew like junk.  You just got to find the right one to use (Zatanna, Red Torando were among the ones that worked best for me) and may also have to boost the character in flight when the gates are farther apart.
-Zatanna is good character to use on things because she can fly, blow up gold objects and go through grates.  Cyborg is also cool cause once you have the space suit when you double jump with him (no matter what suit he's currently wearing) he'll switch to the space suit and fly.

Well if you've read all this you must have had a lot of time on your hands lol.  Thanks for reading and good luck!

**UPDATE 3/20/2015** Since I wrote this review all 3 of the remaining DLCs for the season pass have been released. Due to space limitations I decided to combine my updates on these into one.  My favorite of the three was the Arrow DLC.  Good length, plenty to do and and a cool lego riff by Stephen Amell of his Arrow intro.  My least favorite was the Bizarro DLC.  It was really hard trying to figure out what you were supposed to be doing in that one.  Felt like throwing my controller at my monitor.  The Squad DLC was pretty cool but felt shorter than the others.  All the DLCs give you more cool characters to play around with so worth it for that reason alone.  Now I'm just counting down the days until Lego Jurassic World is released. Can't Wait!

reviewText:
LEGO Batman 3 starts slow and then gets a lot better, and then overwhelms with so much content it's hard to be disappointed.

I don't think I've ever played a game so clearly made with hardcore fans in mind. Not only is LEGO Batman 3: Beyond Gotham a DC fanboy's dream come true (unless you happen to love one of the few characters not included), but also a LEGO fan's too. If you happen to fall into both categories, knowing, for example, both who Mr Plastic is and what LEGO master builds are, then you've hit the jackpot. For everyone else, this is another slick, content-packed LEGO game that will feel incredibly similar to previous LEGO games you've played.

Dropping the open-world design seen in LEGO Batman 2 and the more recent Hobbit game, Batman 3 returns to a series of individual levels and a number of hubs and planets that can be explored. With a storyline that centres on the evil Brainiac's intention to shrink down planets, and the involvement of the Lanterns, an open world wouldn't really work. The result is a game that offers some lovely diverse locations, and a lot of fun, once it actually gets going.

The opening few hours were a bore. Mainly set inside dingy locations or dull space station rooms, it all felt rather 'been there done that'. New playable characters were slow to arrive and the introduction of new suits for characters (giving them new abilities, such as magnetism, electricity, flight, etc) made for a rather prolonged tutorial. I wasn't feeling the love. It was another LEGO game, done well, but there was no spark. And then things suddenly got a lot more interesting.

It takes a while, but once you're outside the game comes alive. Not only do the levels become more colourful (especially the Lantern planet levels) and clever in their design, but the characters can use their abilities more and the increased cast plays off each other very well.

While the game is largely played from the same fixed camera angles the series has always used during levels, meaning you can't pan around to take in the environments, parts of Batman 3 look lovely. A couple of boss encounters really impress, as do a set of shrunken city levels that are entirely made of LEGO. Sure, this isn't a next-gen showpiece, but I paused on more than one occasion to take some snaps. Of course, the audio work here is brilliant, with top notch voice acting to deliver the humorous script, and all the classic music associated with the DC super heroes.

Speaking of the DC heroes, LEGO Batman 3 can't help but suffer to the casual audience in comparison to last year's Marvel Super Heroes game. While Marvel is on a high at the cinema, unless you are really into DC you'll struggle to recognise most the characters here. Batman and the rest of the Justice League characters, along with some of the enemies, will be familiar faces, and if you've played the Arkham games you'll at least know some of the Batman friends and foes, but this will largely be a game of discovery for many players. That's not necessarily a bad thing, and you'll know going in how much fanservice here will excite you or go completely over your head.

Designed for an audience so diverse in age (very young kids through to fully-grown adults with kids of their own), LEGO Batman 3 often feels like it can't quite be challenging enough. I'll admit to being stuck from time to time (entirely down to overlooking objects in the levels that needed to be destroyed in order to be built into something else), but the puzzles are borderline pre-school level and the mini-games are atrocious (aside from the shmup-lite sequences that resemble a super simple Resogun). A set of stages in which you have to run around Tron-like worlds are so poor I'm surprised they made the cut, and offer nothing other than tedium.

If you're disappointed about the lack of open world, you can explore the Lantern planets via a moon base (Oa, for example, lets you drive vehicles around, but they all offer plenty to do along with the moon hub itself) and the hub zones (Batcave, The Watchtower and Hall of Justice) have so much to find that you'll be playing well beyond the end of the main missions. As is always the case in LEGO games, there are an obscene number of characters to collect, bricks to find and secrets to uncover. This is a massive game that will keep you (and a split-screen friend) happy for a long time if you're into collectables of the DC variety. Freeplay has always been a series staple and it's great here, and there's even a character customisation tool.

LEGO Batman 3 starts slow and then gets a lot better, and then overwhelms with so much content it's hard to be disappointed. It's hard to get really excited about a game that feels largely similar to how the series started with LEGO Star Wars almost 10 years ago on the PlayStation 2, but DC and LEGO fans won't care as much about the sameness. For everyone else there's no doubt this is a classy package packed to the brim with content, but new ideas are definitely needed. LEGO Batman 3 eventually becomes very good but it's time the studio attempted to build a new mould.

reviewText:
Lego Batman 3 is a great game if you want to have fun, as it should be, because that is really what Lego games are about.

You can point out little flaws here and there, but nothing that makes the game unplayable or massively flawed to the average or casual player. One thing to point out is once you do finish the campaign, the game doesn't just end there. You can replay the levels you've already completed, unlock new characters, and you can do all this while playing as pretty much any character you have unlocked. ( Side Note: The whole 'after the game is done' exploring and replaying is known as FreePlay. ) The hours you spend playing the game really come down to the type of player you are. If you just finish the campaign in average time and don't do much else, you can take less than 24 hours to be done with the game. However, if you want hundred percent completion, you can look forward to putting A LOT of hours into the game.

In conclusion, this game is a great buy, especially if you plan on playing even after the campaign. Are there flaws? Yes. There isn't much of a 'open-world' aspect to the game, unlike other Lego games ( for example: Lego Marvel: Super Heroes. ) Some people may not like the game for that reason, but to me, this is a great game overall. The game isn't so difficult that you need a walk-through every mission, and has some humour in cut-scenes that you may get a laugh out of. Overall, great game!

Enjoyable for any DC fan, but I feel as though the only contribution LB3 made to the series was the evolution in character models.

I can see what TT games were trying to achieve by going 'to space', and including new planets to explore, but honestly, it just wasn't as fun as flying around and exploring Gotham in LB2. The mini versions of the lantern planets and some of the non-flat levels made me feel dizzy - perhaps that's just me though.

The celebrity tie-ins were acceptable and amusing for the most-part, but Conan O'Brien? That put me off slightly.

In summary, I'd recommend this game to anyone who has already played LB2, and if you can pick it up cheap and you enjoy spending a few hours doing side missions to unlock your favourite niche DC characters, then it's worth the time investment.

I won't pretend I am a game reviewer, but I have been playing games for a long time now. Family action games don't get any better than this, easily one of the best games of 2014.

Tt raises the bar for family games, and gaming in general. I would recommend this game to anyone, heck I am enjoying this just as much as my siblings.

[New Review]: Batman 3 is no longer a Batman game, instead focusing on Green Lantern lore. There are only a handful of Batman characters you'll see throughout the story, and even then they all play miniscule parts besides Batman, who himself only plays second-fiddle at the best of times. Only two levels have anything to do with Batman, while major characters like Poison Ivy and The Penguin from the last games are nothing but unlockables with no helpful skills.

There is no open world like Batman 2, instead letting you explore a number of sperical levels and three hubs, which isn't necessarily worse, but does feel very limiting. Vehicles are all but worthless, limited to a single level of gold brick races. The introduction of VR missions is very interesting, but fairly limited. The gameplay in general is exactly what you'd expect from a Lego game, though there's less of a grind for studs, but this just refocuses the grind on having to play levels multiple times to get everything, long after studs are worthless.

This game has more bugs than any other Lego game I've played, both progression-blocking and crashing. It is also impossible to get 100% of the acheivements without buying all of the underwhelming DLC. And as much as I enjoyed the old TV series level and characters, Adam West is overplayed SO much in this game that it will stop being cute long, long before you're finished.

If you want to play a BATMAN game, go for Lego Batman 2 instead.

reviewText:
I've played most of Travller's Tales' LEGO games, starting with the very first LEGO Star Wars game, and all the way up to LEGO Batman 2. While I haven't played The Hobbit and Lord of the Rings games, and barely played Marvel Superheroes, I will say that from my experience this is the best LEGO game by TT Games for far.

If you are a fan of DC Comics and everything within, you're gonna love this. While Batman 2 has offered us some sort of DC Superheroes experience, Batman 3 takes it to a whole new level, going Beyond Gotham, which you can feel. I fell in love with this game because it's not Gotham anymore, no more depressing rainy city filled with crime, but space missions, Watchtower and even Lantern Planets instead! Needless to say, there are way more characters than in any TTG game before, and probably it hosts more characters than LEGO Indiana Jones 2 and Star Wars The Complete Saga together!

The story is alright - it involves Brainiac as a main antagonist who we have seen at the end of Batman 2, and Story itself takes us to variety of places. While some characters could have worked better as leads than the others(Bain instead of Solomon Grundy would have been better, imo), the story and characters are still great.

Remember Suit system from Batman 2 where you had to find a specific pad for Batman or Robin with a specific suit? Well, TTG have realised that nobody wants to deal with this anymore and added a free selection of any unlocked suits for characters that have suits, whether during story or free play missions. oh and, Batman and Robin are not the only ones who have got different suits!

Overall, I would say this is the best LEGO game by TTG so far, and it's a must have for any DC Comics fan, no matter your age.

reviewText:
Not recommended? Why. Well because it is only fair to compare this to Lego Marvel Super Heroes. I purchased this for my daughters and frankly Travelers Tales should be ashamed of themselves for this being the more recent of the two, but far lower in quality in almost every way. First of all, LMSH has a true open world. You explore, you can mess around and you have an abundence of side-quests.  LBBG has a quest hub which consists of around 12 'rooms' which really doesn't justify any exploration or provide anything to just play with. Next, the personality of the two games. LBBG gives you an especially simple story with a narrow group of characters that lack any kind of charm. Superman is an egomaniac, Batman is boringly serious and Robin is child-like. To try and make the game amusing they decide to hit the characters with Spectrum energy, a cheap attempt at comedy which the developers cling to for the rest of the story rather than trying to be genuinely creative. LMSH however, gave you a wide and varied cast with some genuine comedy moments. Plus the story itself was genuinely interesting.

So between the two, what does LBBG give you? More characters and more abilities per character. But that is it. Puzzles are more varied at first, but again it seems that the devs ran out of budget or time for the last half of the game resulting in a severe lack of variety in puzzles. The 'space battles' are a 2D side scrolling mess which feels like someone had to toss in some content quickly and this was what they came up with.

Frankly, if they took all of the great bits from LMSH and added the additional characters and abilities from LBBG and put them into Lego Avengers, due to be released in 2016, then it should be an amazing game. As such, save your cash for that release or purchase Lego Marvel Superheroes rather than this half-baked mess in the meantime.

Additionally, it seems that although TT added DX11 functionality, it is very unstable and causes some Nvidia drivers to simply stop responding mid-game. The solution I found is to change the game to use DX9 in the settings or remove the dx11 executable from the directory. Did TT even sit down and test this thing?

reviewText:
The good things about LEGO Batman 3: Beyond Gotham are the things that are good about the whole LEGO series: relatively easy puzzle play, drop in/drop out coop, lots of collectibles, and a general lack of angst and drama. Beyond Gotham goes even farther with tons of post-storyline quests and locations, different fight animations for different characters, and an amazing amount of voice-over recording.

For me, though, my favorite thing about LEGO games is the humor, and I didn't find as much as usual in Beyond Gotham. Maybe it's just that I missed all the inside jokes (I'm less familiar with the DC universe than with other LEGO game topics). Normally, I find myself laughing out loud frequently, and wanting to show all the silly bits to friends. But my snickers-per-minute ratio was far below standard with this particular LEGO game.

So, if you want hours of gameplay, especially co-op with a less-skilled friend, Beyond Gotham is a fine choice. If you want silly humor, there are better LEGO games to start with.

reviewText:
Gameplay: It has the staple LEGO game style.  Break stuff, collect studs, build LEGO objects, solve puzzles, and various interactions of specific objects.  It's the same formula.  A few things have changed though, the game has included costumes with purpose.  In previous LEGO games they would have multiple skins for characters, but they had no primary function outside of aesthetic.  Now each costume has a specific ability.  It's a nice addition though it does make the player have to switch costumes for different tasks quite a bit which is a little tedious.  Having all these costumes on top of having a huge character roster is wonderful.  I've also noticed that the levels feel longer.  They are about a half hour each, and I've noticed that at least one level I entered didn't have a saving checkpoint until over half way through which was an inconvenience.

Puzzles: The puzzles are perhaps a little more difficult this time around, but ever so slightly.  It is still definitely playable for adults and children alike.  This game in the franchise is not an exception in the LEGO game formula in which the puzzles can occasionally feel like artificial barriers.  A new added problem with puzzles is that at least a few options seem viable to solve them.  But the game will only allow you to use one option, so it can be confusing as to which one you think the game expects you to use.  This often occurs because of the different costumes abilities.

Environment: The biggest problem I have with this game is the hugely disappointing lack of exploration. Having played LEGO Marvel Super Heroes I enjoyed the free-roam of New York City immensely.  Not only that, LEGO Batman 2 also had free roam of Gotham!  It feels like a step backwards not to have this free roam area.  It's great that we get to visit all these locations in the DC universe but it feels like I'm getting a few slices of different cakes when I need at least a whole cake before I want to try any other slices.  The worlds that the player does get to visit that are large enough to roam, are completely empty.  There is practically no one in them.  It's isolating and depressing and it leaves much to be desired.  I really feel like the game is playing out linearly.  Playing as superheroes with the linear progression feels like there's even more artificial barriers.  I don't feel like a super hero.  If I am a super hero, than I'm a super hero stuck in a lab rat cage. It's really a shame.  The world feels silent as there's almost no one around you and when there is someone around you it's almost exclusively enemies.  Because the hubworlds are at the locations they are at, this is understandable but it certainly doesn't help the gameplay.  The utilization of vehicles was also great in previous LEGO titles.  Now hold on, LEGO Batman 3: Beyond Gotham also has vehicles, doesn't it?  It's true, it does.  But I have completed 7 missions and spent over 6 hours in the game (roughly 47% of the main story line) and yet still have not accessed a hub world large enough to use a vehicle.  The worlds that I have seen others play on with vehicles lack any enjoyable exploration.  The game blocks off a lot of areas from players until they've progressed in the story.  Again, more artificial barriers.

The game seems to suffer because of a huge polarity in what it knows the players wants it to be and what it provides to the player.  We want to expand from Gotham.  But we didn't want to lose it in the process.  When I say this I mean to say that this is a Batman game, and most of the focus is on batman and robin (of which you play as them in most levels), which is the biggest influence in level design.  Batman and robin can't fly, they're powerful, but navigating the world is difficult for them.  So the levels are designed with that in mind.  The ceilings are low, flying is made more difficult (especially with the inclusion of the requirement of fuel).  Yet, the game gives you super powerful characters to play as.  I think it's appropriate that they call this a Batman game and not a DC Super Heroes game for that reason.  While you can certainly play as those other characters the game is not designed with their powers in mind.

Performance: Many users are reporting Xbox 360 controller issues.  I don't know if it's a universally true issue or if people just refuse to do their own keybinding.  I myself ran across a breif moment with controller issues when I loaded up my game.  Quite hilariously every single command on the screen for navigating the menu would say Enter (no input) to do x." None of the controls were pre-set so I had to manually choose what buttons were assigned to for all the commands
date: but after that everything worked as advertised.   I run the game on max settings and my PC is actually a quite dated gaming laptop (Asus G74SX).  I've encountered only two moments where my frame rate dropped lasting at most 4 seconds each.  I assume these controller issues will be fixed for most people within a short time and when they do this game will be a solid port.\n\nMeta: If you want to get a better idea of the disparity between what the game is and what it tries to be look at the OPENING CUTSCENE when you start the game up.  It starts off in Gotham
recommended: you see a few armed men from jokers gang on a rooftop.  There's tagged graffiti of Joker on a wall nearby and smoke rises from other buildings in the city.  The thugs start to become frightened as Batman closes in on them - they're not completely one dimensional evil minions.  Batman captures them with awesome moves and stealth
hoursPlayed: capturing the frightened foes.  Then we finally see Batman grapple on to another roof top; he jumps away and with his wings extended in front of the moon and its an epic display.  Now that game looked great! It had serious atmosphere.  It looked like you were on the rooftop of an inhabited world where you were having an impact on those who reside there.  You're fighting crime.  Making a difference.  If I were playing a game like that

Do yourself a favour and play Marvel Lego instead, which isn't as bad as this entry.
Or play the earlier Batman titles.

The Lego games used to be short, action-packed punches of fun and entertainment but now they're long-winded and boring slog-fests. Tedious and pointless cutscenes filter in at every level breaking up the pacing of the level, boring level design and excessive waves of enemies that never end leaving you with never a good chance to explore the level and collect things which was the main aspect of the Lego titles.

The story is sub-par and the cutscenes aren't anything to write home about, especially now that we've got voice-acting, with their inclusion the cutscenes are all bogged down and a chore to go through whereas in previous unspoken titles the scenes were more punchy and to the point.

Levels feel extremely long and tedious, it's not so much a game you can pick up and have a quick round in as you'll find yourself slogging through longer than you expected, which is something I also noticed in the previous title of Marvel, but alas I've yet to see someone else suffer of the same issues.

The combat feels like a dodgy Arkham system, where in your character will sometimes jump to the enemy and hit them but sometimes you end up just comboing air as enemies wail on you. Characters who have ranged weapons will also end up melee-ing most of the time as well.

Sometimes in combat, like in the previous Marvel title, a character will perform a finisher on a mob, normally this wouldn't be too bad if they weren't so long and took you out of the combat. It slows the pace and after you've seen it once it gets extremely boring and monotonous.

Main characters also have access to different suits, unlike in Batman previous however, where only Batman and Robin could change, multiple characters in this game can change suits, making pretty much most of them boringly the same. The intricacies are lost.

Character creation seems bland and stale, even in Marvel you could at least have more variety in the weapons you had, but in this game, not so much, which is unfortunate.

Re-running levels has now officially become the most painful of processes in the Lego titles, cutscenes that can't be skipped litter throughout and you'll find yourself being burnt out when all you need is that one minikit towards the end of the level.

All in all, the devs have truly lost sight of what made the early games so amazing and since Batman 2 we've gotten bad after bad. If you must buy this game, get it on sale.

This game elaborates on the tool specific costumes from previous LEGO Batman games, adding more suits for Batman, Robin and other characters.  The story is pretty light, but is entertaining enough to keep you playing.  As LEGO games always are, the story is childish; there are many instances of cringe-worthy jokes being littered through each scene.  But, as LEGO stories go, it's good enough for an original tale.
All in all, LEGO Batman 3 is a fun, family-friendly adventure taking you through the heart of the DC Universe.  So many amazing chracters are represnted, and their inclusions alone should warrant interest from any avid DC fan.

This game is a somewhat logical progression from LEGO Batman 2 in that it is more expansive and adds more characters. However, a more apt title for the game would be LEGO Justice League. Don't get me wrong -- I loved playing with the other DC characters in LB2 and I'm enjoying playing with the DC characters in this one. But if you're looking for something more Batman-centric, this could be a bit of a letdown. That being said, just buy it anyway because it's fun (and currently on sale). The season pass is also worth the investment.

The game runs smoothly and the graphics look good on my quad-core AMD. Although some cut scenes play statis or lose sound and the image may stutter -- it's nothing major and it is more than likely my laptop. Game looks great through am HDMI connection to TV as well. The new feature to change character costume abilities as needed is very convenient. The pop-up game hints are really very annoying. This game features save checkpoints like the previous one, however, the checkpoints can be few and far between. If you're running out of gaming time and encounter a checkpoint, keep in mind that the next save point could be in 10 minutes or much longer.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend this game, especially to fans of LEGO games.

There are many things that make this game good, but to list a few:

-This game is what Lego Batman 2 was supposed to be
-This game is like Lego Marvel for DC maniacs
-This game is funny
-This game has good DLC
-This game has a mostly justified price
-This game has good DC references
-This game has good graphics
-This game has good music
-This game has fun Lego game mechanics and gameplay
-This game has powers (explosives, stealth and etc.) that aren't as situational as Mega Man (You can use powers to change combat, unlock secrets and progress through the stages)
-This game has long stages that offer checkpoints in case if you get tired or want to take a break


However, this game has some flaws, including:

-Too many characters with similar powers
-This game has bad sound design within levels
-This game has laggy cutscenes (I don't have a high-tech gaming computer, but Lego Marvel, Lego Movie, and more have less laggy cutscenes)
-This game has some very easy puzzles
-This game has some very specific controls that can interfere with the game (like tapping B to enable scanning mode as Stealth Suit Batman and holding B to turn invisible while also tapping B to build stuff)
-This game's flying mechanics are hard to manage, but you get used to them
-The flying-in-spaceship levels are a pain in the butt to control (Stage 3)
-This game has no open world unlike Lego Batman 2 and Lego Marvel and stays akin to having mutiple, small hubs like The Lego Movie Videogame (Personally, I think the open worlds were bland and forgettable)

Overall, this game is great and is way better than the last few games. If you are a fan of Lego games and/or DC comics, you will enjoy this game. You can mostly overlook the game's flaws as there is more good than bad in this game. This game is a blast for anyone, regardless of age.

What I love about Lego games is that they are different; they aren't your typical games where the only thing in between you and your objective is death, but there are always unique obstacles where you need to think and scan the environment, because even the smallest of bricks can help you progress. They give you new perspectives and add hilarious alternations to famous, well known storylines. Well let me tell you something.........LEGO BATMAN 3 THROWS EVERYTHING THAT MAKES A GOOD LEGO GAME AWAY AND RUINS THE BATMAN FRANCHISE. As a fan of the amazing firs two lego batman games, I had high standards but wasnt going to critisize one of the games in a franchise I love, but this terrible game has pushed me to do this and tell you all why this game wouldnt be worth getting, even if it was FREE. First of all lets focus on the title: 'Beyond Gotham'. This title basically explains that there is ABSOLUTELY NO GOTHAM IN THIS GAME.....NONE!!! The only time you enter gotham (once), is for a mission, where everything is shrunken and you are limited to a REALLY small area. I bet your thinking, 'So forget gotham, we have a new city and all of space to explore!). Well first of all, there is no other city, and second of all, SPACE SUCKS! You can only visit about 5 different planets, which are SMALLER THAN ****, and they have nothing except a different color, plants, and a couple of bad guys on each planet. You also get a useless tour of each planet from daffy duck (thats right, daffy duck) where you literally walk around the planet with him and defend him from a couple of enemies EVERY SINGLE TIME! There is nothing to explore or any quests/temples/jungles/other characters/boss fights/structures/special items ect. (I could go on). All you get to explore is a TINY (thought bigger than every planet) hall of justice and of course the only thing they got fight in this game, the watchtower. To add to the freeroam and not-so-open world, a lego game needs side missions. Batman Beyond Gotham has absolutely no side missions that actually require effort. Take the killer moth mission for example, all you need to do (no joke whatsoever) IS TURN A COUPLE OF LIGHTS ON WITH THE PUSH OF A BUTTON, just to lead killer moth to WHERE HE WAS PLANNING ON GOING IN THE BEGINNING. Basically  other side missions pretty much have you break something or collect something within a limited time.......BORING!!! NOW your probably thinking, 'at least we have our good old batman storyline and our favorite notorious villians plotting', well guess what, throuought the whole campaign, ALL the villians except braniac, ARE ON YOUR SIDE!.....Thats right, you only fight killer croc once in the beginning and thats pretty much it. The rest is taking on braniac and his minions, which weapons or appearance dont vary at all. The storyline is that brainiac is shrinking earth and you must stop him, and there is no change or plot twist through the whole story. Its all the same: you go to each of the planets, steal a ring, and fight braniac. Its way too predictable and definetely way too short. There are only around ten missions which feel no different to the others. Now with the characters, this is definitley where Batman Lego really let us down. None of the characters had any deep personality like in the other games: Joker has some failed attempts at some jokes, and batman in completely expressionless (and not in the cool batman-ish way). Now with our final, most important, most failed element of Batman Lego 3......the gameplay. First: the missions. As I previously said about lego games being for thinking and solving puzzles, lego batman 3 is the complete opposite. Each level basically requires you to pull a lever or push a single button, WHILE BEING OVERWHELMED BY ENDLESS WAVES OF ENEMIES. This game has become just another fighting game, where now  your goal is to fight and kill your enemies. Its lost the meaning of lego games and has made beyond gotham a huge disappointment. Now what makes lego BATMAN special? Its the characters (failed), the city (failed), the personalities (failed), the dark atmosphere (failed) and lastly, the vehicles and gadgets. Let me just say that its clear the developers of this game were lazy and didnt bother to add ANY NEW GADGETS. Yes there are new suits, but thats the bare minimum. Now with the vehicles that we were all looking forward to blasting our foes to pieces with, guess what, THERE ARE NONE! Thats right, not ONCE in the game do you get to control or even see the batmobile/batplane/batcopter/batbike/batsub/batboat. All we get is a crummy bat-space ship sort of thing. Of course spaceships SOUND cool but actually using them is TERRIBLE! You get a zoomed out side-view of your ship and only fly around a single structure, only being able to shoot in a STRAIGHT LINE! Now I WOULD say that the replayability is good.........but you just cant enjoy something when its forced on to you. In every level is some special (but ultimatley useless) item that can only be accessed with a character that your not given, meaning later you will have to replay the level with characters you might not even want to play with. Overall I guess the only good thing was the extra level, where you play as a retro-comic themed batman, robin, and batgirl agains retro-comic themed villians (which you acually get to fight this time). That was fun but ultimately this game that had so much potential, ended up terrible and I would definitley NOT recommend this game. Batman Lego 3 Beyond Gotham has scored a pathetic 3-4/10 in my opinion. Go save yourself some money and get the second batman lego, which I really enjoyed and really captures the batman universe.

What I love about Lego games is that they are different; they aren't your typical games where the only thing in between you and your objective is death, but there are always unique obstacles where you need to think and scan the environment, because even the smallest of bricks can help you progress. They give you new perspectives and add hilarious alternations to famous, well known storylines. Well let me tell you something.........LEGO BATMAN 3 THROWS EVERYTHING THAT MAKES A GOOD LEGO GAME AWAY AND RUINS THE BATMAN FRANCHISE. As a fan of the amazing firs two lego batman games, I had high standards but wasnt going to critisize one of the games in a franchise I love, but this terrible game has pushed me to do this and tell you all why this game wouldnt be worth getting, even if it was FREE. First of all lets focus on the title: 'Beyond Gotham'. This title basically explains that there is ABSOLUTELY NO GOTHAM IN THIS GAME.....NONE!!! The only time you enter gotham (once), is for a mission, where everything is shrunken and you are limited to a REALLY small area. I bet your thinking, 'So forget gotham, we have a new city and all of space to explore!). Well first of all, there is no other city, and second of all, SPACE SUCKS! You can only visit about 5 different planets, which are SMALLER THAN ****, and they have nothing except a different color, plants, and a couple of bad guys on each planet. You also get a useless tour of each planet from daffy duck (thats right, daffy duck) where you literally walk around the planet with him and defend him from a couple of enemies EVERY SINGLE TIME! There is nothing to explore or any quests/temples/jungles/other characters/boss fights/structures/special items ect. (I could go on). All you get to explore is a TINY (thought bigger than every planet) hall of justice and of course the only thing they got fight in this game, the watchtower. To add to the freeroam and not-so-open world, a lego game needs side missions. Batman Beyond Gotham has absolutely no side missions that actually require effort. Take the killer moth mission for example, all you need to do (no joke whatsoever) IS TURN A COUPLE OF LIGHTS ON WITH THE PUSH OF A BUTTON, just to lead killer moth to WHERE HE WAS PLANNING ON GOING IN THE BEGINNING. Basically  other side missions pretty much have you break something or collect something within a limited time.......BORING!!! NOW your probably thinking, 'at least we have our good old batman storyline and our favorite notorious villians plotting', well guess what, throuought the whole campaign, ALL the villians except braniac, ARE ON YOUR SIDE!.....Thats right, you only fight killer croc once in the beginning and thats pretty much it. The rest is taking on braniac and his minions, which weapons or appearance dont vary at all. The storyline is that brainiac is shrinking earth and you must stop him, and there is no change or plot twist through the whole story. Its all the same: you go to each of the planets, steal a ring, and fight braniac. Its way too predictable and definetely way too short. There are only around ten missions which feel no different to the others. Now with the characters, this is definitley where Batman Lego really let us down. None of the characters had any deep personality like in the other games: Joker has some failed attempts at some jokes, and batman in completely expressionless (and not in the cool batman-ish way). Now with our final, most important, most failed element of Batman Lego 3......the gameplay. First: the missions. As I previously said about lego games being for thinking and solving puzzles, lego batman 3 is the complete opposite. Each level basically requires you to pull a lever or push a single button, WHILE BEING OVERWHELMED BY ENDLESS WAVES OF ENEMIES. This game has become just another fighting game, where now  your goal is to fight and kill your enemies. Its lost the meaning of lego games and has made beyond gotham a huge disappointment. Now what makes lego BATMAN special? Its the characters (failed), the city (failed), the personalities (failed), the dark atmosphere (failed) and lastly, the vehicles and gadgets. Let me just say that its clear the developers of this game were lazy and didnt bother to add ANY NEW GADGETS. Yes there are new suits, but thats the bare minimum. Now with the vehicles that we were all looking forward to blasting our foes to pieces with, guess what, THERE ARE NONE! Thats right, not ONCE in the game do you get to control or even see the batmobile/batplane/batcopter/batbike/batsub/batboat. All we get is a crummy bat-space ship sort of thing. Of course spaceships SOUND cool but actually using them is TERRIBLE! You get a zoomed out side-view of your ship and only fly around a single structure, only being able to shoot in a STRAIGHT LINE! Now I WOULD say that the replayability is good.........but you just cant enjoy something when its forced on to you. In every level is some special (but ultimatley useless) item that can only be accessed with a character that your not given, meaning later you will have to replay the level with characters you might not even want to play with. Overall I guess the only good thing was the extra level, where you play as a retro-comic themed batman, robin, and batgirl agains retro-comic themed villians (which you acually get to fight this time). That was fun but ultimately this game that had so much potential, ended up terrible and I would definitley NOT recommend this game. Batman Lego 3 Beyond Gotham has scored a pathetic 3-4/10 in my opinion. Go save yourself some money and get the second batman lego, which I really enjoyed and really captures the batman universe.

There are many things that make this game good, but to list a few:

-This game is what Lego Batman 2 was supposed to be

-This game has a mostly justified price

-This game has good music

-This game has long stages that offer checkpoints in case if you get tired or want to take a break


However, this game has some flaws, including:

-Too many characters with similar powers
-This game has bad sound design within levels
-This game has laggy cutscenes (I don't have a high-tech gaming computer, but Lego Marvel, Lego Movie, and more have less laggy cutscenes)
-This game has some very easy puzzles
-This game has some very specific controls that can interfere with the game (like tapping B to enable scanning mode as Stealth Suit Batman and holding B to turn invisible while also tapping B to build stuff)
-This game's flying mechanics are hard to manage, but you get used to them
-The flying-in-spaceship levels are a pain in the butt to control (Stage 3)
-This game has no open world unlike Lego Batman 2 and Lego Marvel and stays akin to having mutiple, small hubs like The Lego Movie Videogame (Personally, I think the open worlds were bland and forgettable)

Overall, this game is great and is way better than the last few games. If you are a fan of Lego games and/or DC comics, you will enjoy this game. You can mostly overlook the game's flaws as there is more good than bad in this game. This game is a blast for anyone, regardless of age.

Like Batman? (or just DC in general) Like Lego? If you answered yes, then you will like this game.

This game is a Lego game, so the mechanics, and gameplay is very much the same as the other games, but with this one it's different.
Lego Batman 3 brings Batman and friends along with over 50 other characters from DC, such as, Shazam, Aquaman, Super Man, etc. People might not like this because it says Batman in the title, and when you play it, it's more of a Green Lantern game with other DC things in it, but if you are willing to realise that it's not just Batman, and take it for what it is, it's probably the best Lego game out there.

There's so much to do in this game it's crazy. I will admit though that the story mode is very boring at the beginning, but once you get to the Lantern levels (spoilers?) the main campain gets much better.
After story mode is completed, there is extra missions, freeplay, Full Lantern planets (all 7) to explore, VR missions (not really), and much more.
Every character is fun to play as, and is mostly different, and every character you see in this game is playable at some point, which is amazing.

If you are willing to get past the first really boring marathon levels of the story, you will have a great time.
